questions.text: A patient with a parotid abscess is planned for incision and drainage (I & D). Which of the following practices will you avoid in this patient?

choices.text: Put an incision that is similar to parotidectomy
Blunt dissection of the pus pockets
Dissection parallel to the facial nerve branches
Wait for the swelling to become fluctuant before performing I & D

questions.solution:
In a case of a parotid abscess, one must never wait for fluctuation or pus point to occur. This is because the superficial layer of parotidomasseteric fascia is tense and the fluctuation will be apparent only in later stages.

A parotid abscess refers to an infection and pus formation in the parotid space. It is caused most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. Post-surgical cases and debilitated patients with stasis of salivary flow are at risk of developing parotid abscesses.

Patients typically present with unilateral swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present. Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan. Multiple small loculi of pus are seen in the parenchyma. Aspiration of abscess can be done to determine the culture and sensitivity of the infective agent. 

Correction of dehydration, improving oral hygiene and promoting salivary flow. Intravenous antibiotics are also used in treatment. 

Surgical drainage under local or general anesthesia is carried out by a preauricular incision as employed for parotidectomy. A skin flap is raised to expose the surface of the gland, and the abscess or abscesses are bluntly opened working parallel to the branches of the VIIth nerve. The skin incision is loosely approximated over a drain and allowed to heal by secondary intention.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with recurrent attacks of tonsillitis and speech difficulties was posted for a tonsillectomy procedure. Which of the following position is used in this surgery?
questions.solution:
Rose position is used in tonsillectomy surgery. 

In Rose's position, the patient is supine, with their head extended. A rubber ring is placed under the head to stabilize it and a pillow is placed under the shoulders to extend the head. Rose's position is also used in adenoidectomy and tracheostomy.

 

Indications of tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication
  • Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech
  • Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)
  • As a part of the surgical management of sleep apnea syndrome, glossopharyngeal neuralgia, and Eagle's syndrome.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of the epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

Other options:

Option A: The sniffing position involves flexion of the neck on the body and extension of the head on the neck which is done during tracheal intubation.

Option B: Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions, and for patients with a nasogastric tube. 

Option C: Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to you with a common cold. Due to this, her voice has changed. Which of the following conditions does not cause a similar voice change?
questions.solution:
Common cold leads to rhinolalia clausa. A large nasopharynx doesn't cause rhinolalia clausa but instead rhinolalia aperta.

Rhinolalia clausa or hyponasality is a lack of nasal resonance for words that are resonated in the nasal cavity. Words with M, N, NG sounds like B, D, G. It is due to the blockage of the nose or nasopharynx.

Common causes of rhinolalia clausa are:

  • Common cold
  • Nasal allergy
  • Nasal polypi
  • Nasal growth
  • Adenoids
  • Nasopharyngeal mass
  • Familial speech pattern.

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital complaining of reduced hearing in the right ear. You perform a diagnostic test using the following instrument. All of the following are uses of this instrument except?

choices.text: To determine the degree of hearing loss

questions.solution:
The image is of a digital audiometer (pure tone audiometer). A digital audiometer is a lightweight device that is portable and can be used to perform hearing tests, including pure tone audiometry. This device does not measure acoustic reflexes. 

Acoustic reflex is measured using the impedance audiometer.

An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing loss at that frequency. This is charted in the form of a graph called an audiogram.

The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A–B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness.

Uses of pure tone audiometer:

  • To measure the threshold of hearing of air and bone conduction
  • Helps to predict speech reception threshold (SRT)
  • To diagnose the type and degree of hearing loss.
  • For the prescription of hearing aids
  • Helps to find the degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes
  • A record can be kept for future reference.

Impedance audiometry includes tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurement, which are objective tests of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing).

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a laryngeal mirror which is identified by its straight shaft without any bends with a mirror at the end.

Indirect Laryngoscopy is done by the use of a laryngeal mirror.

The patient is seated straight opposite the examiner, with the head and chest leaning slightly towards him. He is asked to protrude his tongue which is wrapped in gauze for protection from any inadvertent injury. The tongue is held by the examiner between the thumb and middle finger.

The laryngeal mirror (size 4–6) is introduced into the mouth and held firmly against the uvula and soft palate. It should be warmed and tested on the back of the hand before introduction. Light is focused on the laryngeal mirror and the patient is asked to breathe quietly. Movements of both cords are seen and compared by asking the patient to take deep inspiration (abduction of cords), say “Aa” (adduction of cords), and “Eee” (for adduction and tension).

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy (in order) are:

  • The base of the tongue (posterior one-third of the tongue)
  • Vallecula
  • Median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds
  • Epiglottis
  • Pharyngoepiglottic folds
  • Aryepiglottic folds
  • Arytenoids
  • False vocal cords
  • True vocal cords

Other options:

Options A and C: St. Clair Thompson mirror is the other name for the Postnasal/ posterior rhinoscopy mirror. It has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

Option D: A double hook retractor is used to retract soft tissues during surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with right-sided facial weakness and ear pain. On examination, she has vesicles over her skin and auricle as shown in the image below. She has no other symptoms or comorbidities. Which of the following cranial nerves is predominantly involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
The cranial nerve predominantly involved in this patient is the facial nerve.

The given clinical scenario with right-sided facial weakness, ear pain, and vesicles in the external auditory canal are suggestive of Ramsay-Hunt syndrome. 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also called herpes zoster oticus, is a late complication of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection, that results in inflammation of the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).

The causative agent, the varicella-zoster virus, is a double-stranded DNA virus. Initial infection with the virus causes chickenpox, associated with disseminated vesicular rash and fever. The virus remains latent in a cranial nerve or dorsal root ganglia and subsequently gets reactivated in times of physiological stress or immunocompromised states. This is known as herpes zoster or Ramsay Hunt syndrome when facial paralysis occurs.

It is characterized by a classic triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, otalgia, and vesicles in the auditory canal or on the auricle. Pain is the most common presenting symptom.

Hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo can occur due to vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) involvement, as a result of its proximity to the facial nerve. Involvement of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) results in hoarseness and aspiration. Vesicles develop after the onset of neurological symptoms and are seen over the auricle and along the affected side of the face, scalp, palate, and tongue.

The trigeminal, glossopharyngeal, and hypoglossal nerves can also be involved, in immunocompromised patients.

A Tzanck smear performed on fluid obtained from the vesicles shows multinucleated giant cells using a Giemsa stain, methylene blue, or Wright's stain. MRI can demonstrate inflammation near the geniculate ganglion of the affected facial nerve.

Management includes the administration of antivirals like acyclovir or valacyclovir, to help prevent long-term complications and treatment of pain with NSAIDs or opioid analgesics.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge,  sinusitis, and chronic suppurative otitis media is scheduled for adenoidectomy. Which of the following is a contraindication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The presence of a cleft palate is a contraindication for adenoidectomy. 

Performing an adenoidectomy in a patient with a cleft palate can lead to velopharyngeal insufficiency, a disorder of the velopharyngeal valve. The function of this valve is to separate the oral and nasal cavities during actions like speaking, swallowing, vomiting, blowing, and sucking. Velopharyngeal insufficiency leads to reduced speech intelligence as well as social and functional impairment. Patients have hypernasal speech, compensatory facial grimacing, and misarticulation.  

Indications for adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy
  2. Recurrent sinusitis (Option A)
  3. Chronic otitis media (Option B) 
  4. Chronic suppurative otitis media and recurrent ear discharge
  5. Dental malocclusion (Option D) occurring due to a low-positioned tongue, and separated lips. 

Contraindications of adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Cleft palate or submucous palate
  2. Hemorrhagic diathesis
  3. Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was treated for acute otitis media 2 weeks back presents with fever,  and pain behind his right ear. On examination, tenderness is present over the mastoid and the pinna is pushed anteriorly suggesting acute mastoiditis. A fluctuant swelling is present between the tip of the mastoid and the angle of the jaw. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of Bezold's abscess.

Bezold abscess is defined as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the thin medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck, most commonly into the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The abscess can also take any of the following locations: 

  • Deep to the sternocleidomastoid
  • Along the posterior belly of the digastric presenting as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw
  • The upper part of the posterior triangle
  • Parapharyngeal space
  • Along with the carotid vessels.


Treatment:

  1. Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis
  2. Drainage of the abscess in the neck with insertion of a drain through a separate incision
  3. IV antibiotics

Other options:

Option A: Zygomatic abscess forms due to infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.  Patients present with swelling in front and above the pinna with associated edema over the upper eyelid. Here the pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.

Option C: Luc abscess is defined as a subperiosteal temporal abscess. It develops following the spread of infection from the middle ear along the external auditory meatus, directly, to the temporal region. Swelling is present in the deep part of the bony meatus. 

Option D: Citelli’s abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone. It is also considered an abscess of the digastric triangle. In any case, a diagnosis of Bezold abscess is more appropriate for this patient owing to the location of the abscess.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is being evaluated for sensorineural hearing loss after an episode of meningitis. The patient is screened for the threshold of hearing using a test that comprises the following waveforms. Which waveform represents the lateral lemniscus?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the waveforms seen in brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA), and wave V represents the lateral lemniscus.

Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is an objective and non-invasive method of hearing assessment that detects electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway. Stimuli are applied in the form of clicks or tone bursts, which then elicit brainstem responses. Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10 minutes. 

  • Wave I by the distal part of the vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Wave II by the proximal part of the vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Wave III by the cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV by superior olivary complex
  • Wave V by lateral lemniscus
  • Waves VI and VII by the inferior colliculus

The first, third, and fifth waves are the most stable and are used in measurements.

Uses of BERA are:

  • As a screening procedure for infants.
  • To determine the threshold of hearing in infants also in children, and adults who do not cooperate and are malingerers.
  • To diagnose brainstem pathology, e.g. multiple sclerosis or pontine tumors.
  • To monitor VIII cranial nerve intraoperatively in surgery of acoustic neuroma to preserve the function of the cochlear nerve.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: Direct laryngoscopy was performed to evaluate a 60-year-old man with laryngeal cancer. The tumor was noted in the vocal cord and the anterior commissure. Conservative laryngeal surgery was performed. Which of the following surgeries involves the removal of the affected structures?
questions.solution:
The surgery that involves the removal of the vocal cords and anterior commissure is the partial frontolateral laryngectomy.

This surgery is a type of conservative laryngeal surgery. They're performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening. Conservative surgery cannot be done for all types of laryngeal carcinoma so patients should be carefully selected. 

Types of conservation surgeries include:

I) Cordectomy via laryngeal fissure - The vocal cord is excised after splitting the larynx

II) Partial frontolateral laryngectomy - The vocal cord and anterior commissure is excised

III) Partial horizontal laryngectomy - The supraglottis is excised. This includes the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, false cords, and the ventricle.

The other type of surgery is total laryngectomy where the entire larynx along with the hyoid bone, preepiglottic space, strap muscles, and a few tracheal rings are removed. The tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration. 

The indications of total laryngectomy are as follows:

  • T3 lesions
  • All T4 lesions
  • Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
  • Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement
  • Lesions of the posterior commissure 
  • Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
  • Transglottic cancers with cord fixation.

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident performing endoscopic biopsy from the sphenoid sinus in a COVID patient with suspected mucormycosis. Through which of the following areas will you access the sinus?
questions.solution:
The sphenoid sinus is accessed through the sphenoethmoidal recess which is situated above the superior turbinate.

The ostium of the sphenoid sinus can be located endoscopically 1cm above the upper margin of the posterior choana near the posterior border of the septum.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

Related Pearl: The sphenoid sinus

It occupies the body of the sphenoid

Ostium of the sphenoid sinus is situated high up in the anterior wall and opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, medial to the superior or supreme turbinate

It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Cilia are more marked near the ostium, which facilitates mucus drainage into the nasal cavity

Relations of the sphenoid sinus:

  • The lateral wall of the sphenoid is related to the optic nerve and carotid artery
  • The floor of the sinus is related to the Vidian nerve
  • The anterior part of the roof is related to the olfactory tract, optic chiasma, and frontal lobe
  • The posterior part is related to the pituitary gland in the sella turcica and the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of septal perforation?
questions.solution:
Trauma is the most common cause of septal perforation.

Causes of septal perforation:

  • Trauma - nasal surgery, nose picking, septal cauterization, nasal packing, septal hematoma, foreign bodies
  • Surface irritants - cocaine, heroin, decongestant nasal sprays
  • Infections - syphilis, typhoid, tuberculosis, lepromatous leprosy, rhinosporidiosis, rhinoscleroma, aspergillosis
  • Neoplastic - melanoma, SCC, adenocarcinoma, lymphoma
  • Inflammatory - sarcoidosis, Crohn's disease, RA, Granulomatosis with polyangitis

Small anterior perforations may present with a whistling sound during respiration. Large perforations may obstruct the nose or even bleed due to the formation of crusts.

Treatment depends on the cause. Small asymptomatic perforations can be closed by plastic flaps. In larger perforations treatment is aimed at keeping the nose crust-free using nasal douches and bland ointments.

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of vertigo in a certain head position. She denies any ear fullness or hearing loss. A Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis and an Epley's maneuver is performed to treat her condition. The symptoms are relieved due to the repositioning of otoconial debris from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo and a positive Dix-Hallpike test is suggestive of benign positional paroxysmal vertigo (BPPV). The otoconial debris are repositioned from the posterior semicircular canal to the utricle to relieve the symptoms of BPPV.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. In up to 90 percent of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley's maneuver on the affected side.

The Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

  Head and neck Body position
Position 1 Head turned 45°  to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2 Head turned with
affected ear up		 -
Position 3 The whole body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a face-down position  
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45° Brought to sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20° -

questions.text: A patient with impacted wax develops a severe cough while performing the following procedure on him. This is due to stimulation of which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
The image shows syringing which is a procedure done for impacted wax. Reflex cough due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus can occur during this procedure.

Wax is made up of sebaceous and ceruminous gland secretions, hair, desquamated epithelial debris, keratin, and dirt. Factors contributing to the accumulation and impaction of excess wax may be a narrow, tortuous external canal, stiff ear, or obstructive lesions in the canal.

Patients with impacted wax may present with impaired hearing, tinnitus or giddiness. Long-standing impacted wax may ulcerate meatal skin and result in the formation of a wax granuloma.

Wax removal is achieved through syringing or other instrumental manipulation. Hard impacted mass may require prior softening with wax solvents in some cases.

The patient is seated, with the ear to be syringed facing the examiner. The patient wears a kidney tray over his or her shoulder and to collect the return fluid, the patient's head is tilted over the tray. A stream of water from the syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus as the pinna is pulled upwards and backward. The ear canal and tympanic membrane must be inspected and dried with a pledget of cotton at the end of the procedure.

Complications of syringing:

  • Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold
  • Rupture of the tympanic membrane
  • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation

Contraindications for syringing:

  • Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation
  • Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves does not contribute to the tympanic plexus?
questions.solution:
The tympanic branch of the facial nerve does not contribute to the tympanic plexus.

The tympanic plexus is formed by 3 nerves :

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve forms the tympanic branch 
  • The sympathetic fibers from internal carotid plexus forms the superior and inferior caroticotympanic nerve. 

The tympanic plexus innervates the tympanic membrane's medial surface, the tympanic cavity, mastoid air cells, and the bony eustachian tube. It also carries secretory fibres for the parotid gland, and in Frey's syndrome, the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve can be sectioned.

questions.text: Which artery among the following could be the source of bleeding in a case of epistaxis not controlled by external carotid artery ligation?
questions.solution:
Ethmoidal artery can cause epistaxis not controlled by external carotid artery ligation.

The ethmoidal artery is a branch of internal carotid artery, whereas sphenopalatine, greater palatine and facial artery are branches of the external carotid artery. Hence if the bleeding is not controlled by external carotid artery ligation, the subsequent step would be to ligate the ethmoidal artery.

Epistaxis may be classified as anterior or posterior epistaxis.

  Anterior epistaxis Posterior epistaxis
Site Little's area or anterior part of the lateral wall Posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity, or difficult to localize
Age Children, young adults >40 years of age
Cause Usually trauma Spontaneous, due to hypertension or IHD
Bleeding Mild, easily controlled with conservative measures (pressure, anterior nasal pack) Severe requires hospitalisation and posterior nasal pack

Little's area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the site of epistaxis in 90% of the cases.

Four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called the Kiesselbach’s plexus. This area is exposed to the drying effect of inspiratory current and to fingernail trauma and is the usual site for epistaxis in children and young adults.

The four contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The stepwise management of epistaxis:

  1. Pinching the nose 
  2. Hippocratic or Trotter’s method
  3. Cauterisation
  4. Anterior nasal packing
  5. Posterior nasal packing 
  6. Endoscopic Cauterisation 
  7. Ligation 
  8. Embolization

Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point. The recommended hierarchy of ligation to be followed is Sphenopalatine artery → Internal maxillary artery → External carotid artery → Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external ethmoid (Lynch) incision.

questions.text: Allergic rhinitis is mediated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated immunologic response of nasal mucosa to airborne allergens.

Patients typically present with recurrent bouts of sneezing, nasal obstruction, watery nasal discharge, and itching and clinical signs include allergic shiners (dark circles around the eyes) and allergic salute (black transverse nasal crease on the dorsum of the nose due to repeated upward rubbing).

Treatment options include:

  • Avoidance of the allergen
  • Treatment with drugs like oral antihistamines, intranasal corticosteroids, intranasal cromolyn sodium
  • Immunotherapy is through the delivery of allergen in gradual increasing doses till the maintenance dose is reached. It suppresses the development of IgE. It has to be given for a year to see significant improvement in symptoms.

Intranasal corticosteroids (INCS) remain the preferred monotherapy for persistent allergic rhinitis (AR). However, additional studies support the additive benefit of combination treatment with INCS and intranasal antihistamines in AR. For patients receiving INCS, an intranasal decongestant may be added to the treatment for up to 4 weeks.
